title: Would Pyke fight against the harrowing or join it?
body: Just a showerthought I had, Pyke is already considered undead/supernatural of some sort. Would the creatures in the mist even attack him or just ignore him like another ghoul? Would he take up arms and fight for Bilgewater or join in on the yearly onslaught of the Harrowing?

replies.body: We speculated about this a lot during Pyke's development. We have an answer, I'm curious to hear what you guys think about it before we share ours.

I think he would go about his business as usual. If he's truly undead, he doesn't have to worry about being killed by the Harrowing, right? I imagine he'd just wander about slashing people that were alone like he always does.
I feel like either this is correct, or that he would lay low until the Mist receded. Saves him the trouble of having to kill the damned captains a second time.

> If he's truly undead, he doesn't have to worry about being killed by the Harrowing, right?

There is still the issue of Mordekaiser, though. Pyke might not have to fear death, but he probably doesn't want an evil warlord from the distant past to rule over him more than a captain. And Mordekaiser certainly won't ignore a powerful revenant and let him do what he wants.

That's assuming Mordekaiser is actually leading the Harrowing though. I have a feeling the Harrowing is an event that happens annually on it's own, like a morbid holiday. Probably the mists of the Isles gain strength on certain equinoxes and whatnot, so they'd surge outward over the seas. I don't think Mordekaiser would waste his time on an event that's sporadic and fleeting.

Mordekaiser is truly leading the Harrowing, there is no doubt about it. If you read the set of Shadow Isles pieces that were released at the same time as Kalista, Mordekaiser is clearly in charge. 

Maybe the phenomenon existed before he arrived to the Isles, and he only molded it to his own will, but as of now, he's the chief.

Also, the Harrowing is NOT annual. That's a misconception Riot has battled with for a long time, because they started things off by releasing content about the Harrowing on "real life" Halloween, but the Harrowing can happen seemingly randomly (at least from the Bilgewater point of view). Or at least, in an unpredictable manner.

Mordekaiser "conquered" the Shadow Isles, but he doesn't lead the Harrowings - Mordekaiser wants to conquer the mainland, not launch periodic raids on Bilgewater. The ONE thing about the Harrowings that would indicate that Mordekaiser is not in charge of them is the fact that they happen, and then recede. They do not linger and occupy. Mordekaiser wouldn't waste his time on an undead spook-a-thon of a pirate town that only lasts a night to a few days. If he's leading undead to the mainland, he will do so and conquer the regions he decimates, as he carves a path towards Noxus. He's not bound to the Islands and the Mists like the lesser undead are, and he's got necromancers in his employ, so if he was leading the Harrowings, they would be composed of undead he can detach from the islands with and lay waste to Runeterra.

Also, just because Mordekaiser moved in to the Isles and subjected some of the undead there doesn't mean he's got absolute control over everything there. He's just an interloper who's utilizing the tools at hand, but he is by no means the overarching power on the Isles. The corrupted life waters are the true power that governs the Isles and form the Mist, not Mordekaiser. He's the equivalent of a man who built a fortress in a jungle full of gorillas - he may be able to subjugate the gorillas, but the realm he is in has no lord and master.

That's a valid theory, but nothing you offer as evidence sounds very convincing to me. I suppose we'll just have to wait and see in future lore :)

One small point, though: Mordekaiser could regularly invade Bilgewater just as an easy way to raiser more troops, amassing them until he got enough. As you said, he doesn't care about occupying this island, but it's still the closest settlement, so the more practical source of new souls to enslave.

I feel like he's definitely opposed to the Harrowing. He doesn't seem like the sort who would be okay with someone else taking one of his marks. I'm not sure he'd necessarily fight to keep it away, but I can definitely see him killing anything that gets between him and his target, whether it's a alive or not.

This leads to my biggest unanswered question though - _is Pyke undead?_
We don't have a clear answer at all, and how he interacts with the Harrowing would greatly depend on his life state.

If he's undead, then I would imagine he would be ignored by the other undead, but I believe he would actually fight off the dead in the Mists. They'd be there, trying to take the people on his list, and I don't think he'd allow them to interfere with his revenge. He wants to kill them all, not watch as nameless spirits steal his thunder from under him.

If he's not undead, and instead a supernatural hybrid like how Kassadin is Human/Void, and how Nautilus is Human/Lovecraftian sea horror, then I would imagine he would stay clear of the Harrowings, and keep to himself beneath the waters until it passes. He wouldn't want to be consumed by the dead in the mists, as that would also interfere with his plans for vengeance.

Do you plan to share your answer in this thread at some point? or are you going to reveal it in another way. (_so I can stop manically refreshing this page every hour_) worse than click bait this response :P

Neither. I don’t believe the Harrowing actually means much to Pyke. 

On one hand, if Pyke were truly insane enough that he couldn’t distinguish the living from the undead, then maybe he’d attack them, too. But I don’t think he would be defending anyone or actively “against” the Harrowing. 

On the other hand, then, would he continue killing people while the Harrowing was taking place? Assuming that Pyke was aware that his targets would just be consumed by the Mist instead of actually dying, I think maybe not. Having his victims preserved by the Mist, I think, might ruin the whole point of killing them.

Probably depends on the situation.
At least ingame Pyke seems to have no problem teaming up with people to kill his victims,so he might team up with some undead of the harrowing to kill someone,but he might also do the opposite.
